channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Artist’s Death Sentence Follows a String of Harsh Punishments in Saudi Arabia
item.description: The case of Ashraf Fayadh, who was sentenced to death on charges of apostasy, is one of several that have fueled comparisons between Saudi Arabia and the jihadists of the Islamic State.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Afghan Leaders Try to Halt Exodus, but Pleas Ring Hollow
item.description: The reality of a government in which many senior officials have families who live abroad has made it difficult for Afghanistan’s citizens to accept entreaties to stay home.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan migrants from Mazar-i-Sharif waited for their clothes to dry on the Greek island of Lesbos after crossing the Aegean Sea in a boat from Turkey.

item.title: Myanmar Continues Search After Deadly Landslide at Jade Mine
item.description: The landslide, at a mine in Kachin State, highlighted the primitive conditions of an industry that is highly lucrative but notorious for its secrecy.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Diplomatic Memo: John Kerry Adds Voice to Those Urging Bigger Push Against Islamic State in Syria
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that he would like to see the American-led military and diplomatic effort in Syria “go faster.”
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, puts his shoes on after a mosque visit Monday with Abdullah bin Zayed, the Emirati foreign minister, left, in Abu Dhabi. Mr. Kerry said he wanted military and diplomatic efforts in Syria to “go faster.”

item.title: Nestlé Reports on Abuses in Thailand’s Seafood Industry
item.description: The report on the seafood industry in Thailand cataloged deceptive recruitment practices, hazardous working conditions, and violence on fishing boats and in processing factories.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of Thailand’s seafood workers are migrants who are brought into Thailand illegally by traffickers.

item.title: China Cuts Mobile Service of Xinjiang Residents Evading Internet Filters
item.description: People who had downloaded foreign messaging services and other software were said to be targeted, as part of a new measure in the country’s fractious western territory.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR
item.media:credit: Goh Chai Hin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Urumqi, in China’s Xinjiang region. The area has long been home to experiments in Internet surveillance and censorship.

item.title: Appeals Court Rules Memos on Targeted Killings Can Stay Classified
item.description: A panel decided the government could keep secret documents related to targeted killing of noncitizens abroad because the details of American policy remain classified.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Tribal members, shown in 2013, in the rubble of a building hit by an American drone strike in Yemen.

item.title: U.S. Issues Travel Alert
item.description: According to the alert, the government has information suggesting that extremist groups “continue to plan terrorist attacks in multiple regions.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: David Cameron Says He Will Increase Britain’s Military Spending
item.description: Mr. Cameron told lawmakers that his government would add 12 billion pounds, or about $18 billion, to the defense budget over the next decade.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, with President François Hollande of France in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Global Cooperation: Washington Is Next on François Hollande’s Tour to Press Allies for Anti-ISIS Coalition
item.description: President François Hollande of France must show that he is a wartime leader able to influence policy toward Syria and take an important role in the re-energized battle with Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France is calling on the United States and Russia to “unite our forces” against the Islamic State.

item.title: For Third Day, Brussels Is Paralyzed by Terror Dragnet
item.description: The city remained jittery after a number of false alarms involving hotels and even City Hall, which was closed on Monday.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Security forces stood guard on Rue des Bouchers, a street famous for its restaurants, on Monday in Brussels.

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: 2 Die in U.S. Army Crash
item.description: Two pilots were killed when an Apache helicopter went down in central South Korea during a training mission on Monday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: In France, Some See the Police Security Net as Too Harsh
item.description: With expanded police powers extended for three more months, some, particularly Muslims, question whether the loss of liberties is appropriate.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: China and U.S. Say They’ve Made Strides in Trade Talks
item.description: Negotiations yielded modest commitments from the Chinese, including efforts protecting trade secrets and on opening markets wider to American drug and medical device makers.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Visitors at the large machinery and equipment section of the Canton Fair on April 16, 2014, in Guangzhou, China. Commonly known as the Canton Fair, the China Import and Export Fair is the largest trade show in China and has been held biannually in Guangzhou since 1957.

item.title: Netanyahu Plans Separate Bypass Roads for Israelis in Parts of West Bank
item.description: The prime minister said Israeli drivers would be able to bypass certain intersections in the occupied West Bank, where an Israeli soldier was killed in the latest spate of attacks by Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 4 in Burundi Violence
item.description: In an apparent effort to achieve some neutrality, the four men identified include two from the government and two from the opposition.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Mauricio Macri Took Detour From Life as Scion to Argentine Presidency
item.description: Mr. Macri links his kidnapping 24 years ago to an awakening that put him on a course that would lead him to politics via the world of soccer.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Volkswagen Chief Says Emissions Inquiry May Take Months
item.description: Matthias Müller, VW’s chief executive, also said bringing diesel vehicles into compliance with regulations would be less costly than feared.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Matthias Mueller, chief executive of Volkswagen, said the carmaker is several months away from clarifying who was responsible for the emissions-cheating software.

item.title: Russia Says It Killed 14 ISIS Recruiters in North Caucasus
item.description: The men, accused of smuggling out fighters to join the Islamic State, were killed in two clashes with law enforcement agents, according to Russian news reports quoting a government statement..
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Kenyan Runners Accuse Officials of Stealing From Sponsorship Deal
item.description: Dozens of world-class runners stormed the headquarters of Kenya’s athletics association, accusing top officials of stealing nearly $700,000 from a deal with Nike.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Athletes protesting corruption at the headquarters of the national athletics association in Nairobi, Kenya, on Monday.
